title: Why is school so repetitive and boring? - Quora

response.answer_text: In Malcolm Gladwell’s book Outliers, he states that there are 3 things needed for work to be meaningful: complexityautonomyand a clear relationship between effort and rewardStudents may be uninspired because the curriculum is too easy and doesn’t challenge the way the students think. Most likely though…and also the reason why I’m not working on an assignment in the class I’m in right now…is the fact that there is no clear relationship between effort and reward for students. Sure, you do the assignment to get good grades. And good grades lead you to good colleges. Which then gets you good jobs. But right now, none of that effort is really given a result. What’s the point in one of those busy work assignments? Does it teach us time management? Maybe how to find words in a word search better? Or to be able to solve logic puzzles more easily? Because surely, when I become a lawyer or a doctor, I will need to know which house had which person of a different nationality and a certain type of cigar and pet. (I’m referring to one of Einstein’s logic puzzles.) Either way, the assignment seems useless and therefore students give little care about it. It doesn’t challenge them. Granted, some end up doing it and turning it in any way because it’s something you can do without thinking much, but the question of why still exists. What I wish schools would do better at is teaching students on how to adult. Help us find jobs, learn how to deal with confrontation or communication better, teach us how to create a study or learning system catered to our needs. Teach us about taxes, focus on the system of governments and how things are in our country and why. I don’t want to wait for senior year to start learning about this. Trust me, if I can shoot a gun or drive a car or get a job before I’ve had the opportunity to analyze the government’s role in things, or before I have an idea of what different high-paying jobs entail, or before I’ve learned about basic adulting problems and how to overcome them, there’s something wrong with more than students being bored.

For the most part? Because it’s too easy. The American school system, assuming that that was the specific school system of this question, lacks a sense of rigor in their classes. I know what you may be thinking: b-b-but there are plenty of honors and AP classes for high schoolers to take!! Yeah there are, but what people often forget to consider is elementary school children. In my school at least, there were “advanced” classes, but there were certain exams that would determine whether or not you could take them. These standardized tests were mostly on how well students could answer questions before the students were taught the information. Because the information was so foreign to students, they did not realize a purpose in trying. The US education system continually neglects the development of critical thinking skills, likely skills much more important than the things that they are actually teaching. When children are unmotivated by these tests, they consequently will be put in the lower classes. Schools tend to believe that these children are not smart because of all the low test scores; however, the real problem is that they just don’t want to try. And why would they? Because of grade inflation, many ‘smart enough’ students are able to not even try and pass their classes. American students are unmotivated in their schoolwork. Additionally, these students are in the United States. They know that even if they don’t end up successful, they won’t have to worry because everything will work out eventually. Because of this (dare I say) privileged attitude, they don’t even have a point to try. When they aren’t trying, they do not perform to their best, and their teachers think classes are too hard.
